Award.AwardTitle: School Safety, Security, and Educational Progress

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1625703
Anthony A. Peguero
Virginia Tech

As the United States continues to be increasingly immersed in a global competitive market, ensuring the educational progress of all youth, as well as competitive and innovative workforce, contributes to the nation's economic growth and sustainability. Moreover, adult socioeconomic disadvantages and advantages faced can be often traced to youth differential educational experiences, achievement, attainment, and progress. It has become clear that school safety is fundamental for facilitating learning and positive educational outcomes for youth and increasing school security measures as well as stringent control practices have become a common as an approach towards school safety. But, there is growing scrutiny that school surveillance and security practices may be conditioning youth to interpret surveillance, law enforcement presence, and juvenile and criminal justice system interventions as a "normal" part of the school learning environment or experience for all youth. Some researchers denote that harsh or stringent school safety or social control policies are having detrimental educational consequences for marginalized youth, such as racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants. Considering that it is projected that the youth population will become mostly compromised of racial and ethnic minorities as well as one in three youth will have at least one immigrant parent, understanding the relationship between school safety, security, and educational progress for the fastest growing segments of the United States youth population is imperative.

Of course, safety is paramount for learning and educational outcomes for all youth. There is some disagreement, however, if this current approach of increased social control within schools is ensuring educational progress or success, especially for marginalized and vulnerable youth. Thus, this research will draw from three nationally representative data (School Survey on Crime, Safety and Educational Longitudinal Study of 2002, and Common Core Data) as well as incorporate multilevel statistical analyses in order to further our knowledge about the relationship between school safety and educational progress by exploring two broad research questions. First, how are school safety and security policies influencing school-level educational progress as well as the implications for racial, ethnic, and immigration educational inequalities? Second, how are school safety and security policies influencing student-level educational progress, especially for racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants? Although security measures and control practices have become ubiquitous within schools, there is limited knowledge about how securing schools is contributing to educational progress and success, in particular for racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants. This proposed research seeks to contribute to developing knowledge about safety, security, and educational progress within the United States school system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has become clear that school safety is fundamental for facilitating learning and positive educational outcomes for youth; and increasing school security measures as well as stringent control practices have become common as an approach towards school safety. However, there is growing scrutiny that school surveillance and security practices may be conditioning youth to interpret surveillance, law enforcement presence, and juvenile and criminal justice system interventions as a “normal” part of the school learning environment or experience for all youth. Some researchers note that harsh or stringent school safety or social control policies are having detrimental educational consequences for marginalized youth, such as racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants. Therefore, this research draws upon three nationally representative data sets (School Survey on Crime, Safety and Educational Longitudinal Study of 2002, and Common Core Data) in order to further our knowledge about the relationship between school safety and educational progress by exploring two broad and overarching research questions. First, how are school safety and security policies influencing student-level educational progress, especially for racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants? Second, how are school safety and security policies influencing school-level educational progress, and what are the implications for racial, ethnic, and immigration educational inequalities? The following is a general discussion about the findings associated with these two research questions followed by a brief discussion about the associated broader impacts.

 

It is important to note that an increasing population of racial and ethnic minority youth and children of immigrants are not associated with increased school-level disorder and violence at school. Counter to much social, cultural, and public discourse, as the children of immigrants’ population increases within a school, it is associated with a decrease in school-level disorder and violence. With these findings noted, however, an increasing population of racial and ethnic minority youth is linked with increased school security enforcement (i.e., law enforcement, school security officer, and school resource officers) and school security process (i.e., control access to school buildings during school hours, metal detectors, random sweeps for contraband, security cameras, and etc.). Increasing levels of school security enforcement and school security process are not associated with educational progress or success (i.e., achievement, graduation, or going to college). In other words, school safety and security policies are not improving school-level educational progress. Increased school punishment practices (i.e., out-of-school suspensions and in-school-suspensions) are having a detrimental consequence on educational progress or success. In essence, increased school-level punishment practices are contributing to increased levels of underachieving, decreasing levels of graduation, and lower odds of going to college for racial and ethnic minority students and children of immigrants. 

 

Increasing levels of school security enforcement and school security process are not associated with student-level educational progress or success (i.e., reading and math achievement, high school graduation or completion, college enrollment, and educational attainment) for all students. School punishment practices are having a detrimental consequence on educational progress or success for all students. Being punished increases the likelihood of dropping out and diminishes educational attainment for all students; however, the negative effect of school punishment on the odds of dropping out and lower educational attainment is relatively worse for racial and ethnic minority students and children of immigrants. Results suggest that racial and ethnic minority students and children of immigrants have comparatively lower perceptions of their schools as just and fair (i.e., everyone knows what the school rules are; if a school rule is broken, students know what kind of punishment will follow; the school rules are fair; school rules are strictly enforced; and the punishment for breaking school rules is the same no matter who you are). This finding is problematic because lower perceptions of their schools as just and fair contribute to increased risks of dropping out and lower educational attainment. Meanwhile, it is also important to highlight that improving racial and ethnic minority students’ and children of immigrants’ perceptions of their schools as just and fair can reduce their risk of dropping out as well as their educational attainment.

 

The findings revealed in this study clearly demonstrate it is paramount to find a right balance between school safety measures and educational processes. For instance, even though some argue that there is a conceptual link between discipline and academic achievement, some evidence suggests that school safety and security practices do not clearly benefit educational progress. In fact, the results from this study suggest that punitive school practices are having detrimental educational consequences for racial and ethnic minority youth and the children of immigrants. Although there are some that argue that school safety and security policies aim to provide healthy and safe learning environments, it is apparent that overuse of school securitization and strict schools may be unintentionally funneling students out of the educational system.
